abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Sana'a Basin Water
            Management Project for the Republic of Yemen were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: projects should not underestimate the difficulty
            in implementing activities in the water sector in Yemen
            given the number, organizational structure, and weakness in
            capacity of Government of Yemen (GOY) institutions involved
            in Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM).
            Demonstration of new irrigation technologies to improve
            irrigation efficiency in pilot farms was very effective in
            expanding modern irrigation in rural Yemen. Projects should
            avoid establishing legal conditions or requirements that are
            clearly beyond the scope of the project to deliver. Timely
            action will have been better in recognizing the need for
            amending the Development Credit Agreement (DCA) when it was
            decided (2007) to consider farmer installation of localized
            irrigation equipment using equipment supply contracts, with
            outcome-based incentive structure for farmers. This new
            mechanism for transferring the responsibility of installing
            conveyance and distribution system to farmers worked very
            well with improvement in the pace of installation. It is
            crucial for the Management to be involved in resolving the
            institutional issues of the Government in the early stage of
            the project implementation. GOY officials should be fully
            involved from project identification to appraisal phases.
            Involvement of national consultants during these stages as
            counterparts to the foreign consultants would lighten the
            burden of GOY officials but the chance of on-the-job
            training of GOY officials would be lost, which would result
            in delay in project start-up due to lack of capacity.
